88CD7149AB99426C89543C54728BF315.description: Represent achievements and technologies of the contemporary world that have their origins in the achievements and technologies of societies studied (e.g., weapons, dyes, medications, tools, transportation methods, navigation instruments, architecture, printing, mathematics).

FD3A3BAAB53D461986F2D46040B8CE1C.description: Discern the influence of the tools and other technologies of one society studied upon another society studied.

30F7902FDC724FB09AD3A026F6E5C498.description: Explain the impact of tools and other technologies developed in past societies on the economies and lifestyles of those societies

9C1B68A2D743472CAEC997D1BF8089CD.description: Illustrate on a timeline the significant scientific, mathematical, technological, artistic, and cultural achievements of past societies.

8919E1C7F7A74CC38C75A66CBD3D4001.description: Determine the influence of technologies of past societies studied on contemporary society

9577F168B08B42189AEF188A8815D5F3.description: Assess the importance of trade relations and transportation systems for prosperity in the societies studied, and make generalizations with reference to contemporary Canada.

645AE5C9B6874C27868A82E0266A3233.description: Compare the prosperity of societies studied, and infer reasons for similarities and differences.

837B76DD118A49CF8A1D8332F653C888.description: Investigate motives for trade, approaches to trade, and trading patterns of societies studied, to assess the effects on the economy and prosperity of that society.

013A8D8167EF4DF0851050FCE9C5F1E0.description: Analyse the impact of physical geography on modes of transportation in the societies studied.

A83E9C22649547959154EFA59725E756.description: Appraise the significance of trade and transportation in the development of the societies studied.

24B324D4FF9142359009FD37F3208BF8.description: Research the processes for decision making regarding production and distribution of wealth and resources in the societies studied.

ADBE0037E36F48F485987165E47803AD.description: Compare the perspectives regarding the distribution of resources in the societies studied, and assess the results in terms of consequences for the populations of the societies.

BA93B0F19E794594A8266C5FE3E59767.description: Investigate the strategies used to acquire and distribute resources in the societies studied.

C37FD8827C5249DEB188F6845CFC9A8A.description: Compare differing perspectives regarding the acquisition and distribution of resources and wealth in the societies studied.

19300899F47744568E963C53F83A259B.description: To examine various worldviews about the use and distribution of resources and wealth in relation to the needs of individuals, communities, nations, and the natural environment and contribute to sustainable development. (RW)

55B5547F6FC043B69B757649C2075C9D.description: Compare roles within societies studied to those in contemporary Canadian society

D317053DB0BA4BAB8D4145D108628094.description: Compile an inventory of the diverse roles and responsibilities of people within the societies studied, according to various classifications (e.g., gender, age, vocation, social class).

A98798FA28454DDCBE09ABD9B2F61B5B.description: Explain the means to achieving rights in the societies studied, and compare this to contemporary Canadian society.

67C1991DE2E84F4B841B9E9840F5BBD7.description: Examine the rights and responsibilities of people as they existed within the societies studied, and compare findings to contemporary Canadian society.

82661C598DDC448BB06ED507D69544C7.description: Investigate examples of the oppression of rights of particular groups or individuals in societies studied including examples in Canada (e.g., slavery, limited franchise, restrictions on property ownership).

54B615D57F954B5AA39B6E80C45AAA42.description: Differentiate the criteria for citizenship in the societies studied with that in contemporary Canadian society.

2E7109D2AC2A4EBBA8FBB7FC6865DEC3.description: Investigate the roles and responsibilities of members of the societies studied and those of citizens in contemporary Canada.

AF2074315DE34D6F9D0ED72BDA12912E.description: Evaluate the authenticity and validity of information sources used in the inquiry process.

90561956DC9C4DFBAFF34052BFA27541.description: Conduct an inquiry regarding the initial interaction of North American Aboriginal peoples with Europeans, comparing the worldviews of the two.

39429ADB53D44D39B33D79C987D2F7CD.description: Assess the treatment of indigenous populations by the imperialists in the societies studied.

B4E34E1721B24200BC04B1E0268D4D1A.description: Research the imperial activities of a society studied, and critique the reasons for imperialism in the context of the time period (e.g., Macedonia, Rome, England, Spain, France, Mongolia).

BD507216666A4B60A65768826C1C0DDC.description: Analyze the impact of empire-building and territorial expansion on indigenous populations and other groups in the societies studied.

66C62B9EA77F4CB093D87E4C105848F6.description: Compare the distribution of power and the application of authority of a society studied to contemporary Canadian society.

33F581663E0241A3A1462F67857286AB.description: . Draw conclusions about the effect of the rule of law on the worldview of the societies studied.

B62E6398F00640638629684C388F0D68.description: Define the concept of the rule of law and trace its origins in the societies studied.

D00E7C2BFBD1417FBF54547E6CEAFF05.description: Explain the reasons underlying the existence of a particular system of government at a specific moment in the history of the societies studied.

E92CD1C49169419E85C107E58B698D72.description: Interpret the effect of the system of government on the worldview of the societies studied, in terms of who had power, and how government leaders obtained power (e.g., Iroquois chiefs chosen by clan mothers, European leaders selected by elite males) and how power was exercised.

1C7457260901481DBC1E99100FC84CD4.description: Investigate and classify the systems of government in place at different periods in the history of the societies studied (e.g., democracy, consensus, monarchy, autocracy, military regime).

1E032CA7DFA04F0AB09519A05248B6DA.description: Differentiate the essential characteristics of various systems of government, including democracy, consensus, monarchy, autocracy, and military regime

CD893F5222D7410582C807B27D870D47.description: Examine concepts of power and authority in the governance of the societies studied.

8A5F16049C0A45DB90170F196FAE5E3D.description: To investigate the processes and structures of power and authority, and the implications for individuals, communities, and nations. (PA)

16A9C7CBFD18487E8E3F183013FED70E.description: Construct an inventory of references to traditional oral narratives found in current popular media, and determine the relevance of traditional narratives to contemporary society.

9122C9F912D645E0A0B682FAE495A6BE.description: Analyze the impact of knowledge acquired from historical events on the future of contemporary societies (e.g., the decline of the Roman Empire; the attempted annihilation of indigenous cultures and languages, the power of the church; ethnocentrism; the concentration of power in the organization of large corporations; the contribution of indigenous peoples to the survival of newcomers at the time of contact, and the willingness to share the bounty and abundance of the land, sometimes through sophisticated arrangements known as Treaties).

885515246E454AA4BB6AD8CD0494464C.description: Identify ideas, images, and symbols in contemporary life that have their roots in societies of the past (e.g., political, artistic, recreational, technological, mathematical, and scientific).

0A542E579FD841F3A09177FA2302CD0F.description: Determine the influence of societies of the past on contemporary life in Canada.

921B2EF532244EE5B031A286D4782124.description: Analyze the effects of colonization, territorial expansion, and empire-building on the natural environment.

BF2470D78A5E4154B8D926001088F135.description: Analyze the influence of the natural environment on the territorial expansion, colonization, or empire-building in the societies studied.

1E8BF84310F54B5CB4F8D6210043FF35.description: Explain the effect of the natural environment in the progress or decline of the societies studied.

9D72293A62B1445DACB47F42FFBBDF8D.description: Give examples of ways in which the development of societies studied impacted the natural environment

EACB02573C864AD4807DA6D1F78DD86F.description: Give examples of ways in which the natural environment influenced technological development in the societies studied.

A0A6CCAC0E4043AEB03DD0B16136786F.description: Connect the characteristics of the natural environment with the settlement and movement of people in the societies studied

BD465EDE71224383B68BC7E1715C8F50.description: Explain the influence of the major water systems, the topography, and the climate on the ways of life and worldviews in the societies studied.

F4C783E7C74D47FFB45C6E942C477929.description: Assess the relationship of the natural environment in the development of a society

A95DDB5D25FB4014BDAD90F93540BBDC.description: Judge the importance of an event in the history of the societies studied to the people in the society, in historical context as well as to the current era.

7306820EED0F4581BD8BF669A57D84C2.description: Relate the origins and the repercussions of an event in the history of the societies studied.

7530D9E330514EDB93F09EBD0E84E84F.description: Represent in a timeline the key historical events in the societies studied.

1D8C975967D64812974A3C0209D3647E.description: Synthesize the significance of key historical events in societies studied.

A31818CB7380455EB12295D204AC06C9.description: Recognize the dynamic nature of historical knowledge by identifying examples of changes occurring in the interpretation of history as a result of new information uncovered or acknowledged.

C6C2B43C75C248E3A5AA04F689BB5CAA.description: Investigate the role of literature, visual arts, music, newspapers, photographs, and other artifacts in obtaining information about past societies.

728768EC5C8247929AE60EEDB9FAE095.description: Present results obtained and techniques used in ongoing archaeological digs (e.g., Wanuskewin, Eagle Creek; Point-à Callières, Montréal; Pompéi, Italy; Dufferine Terrace, Québec City; Fort Temiscaming, Québec; Ahu o rongo, Easter Island).

DF67AA5FFA504C32AB52BE4946A36FB3.description: Explain various technologies used in archaeology (e.g., shovels, brushes, carbon dating, GPS cartography, satellite imagery).

0C1B87C5234A45A0AC8222F5433BD373.description: Describe the role of archaeology in obtaining information about societies of the past.

21F4B25F15FB4F4FA9798C9ABE6025C3.description: Analyze the advantages and disadvantages of oral accounts as sources of information about historical events.

542FE13E21F04C7DB2DDF5FED3BAC3A0.description: Examine the challenges involved in obtaining information about societies of the past.

83AFC18D770A477D97827FFF96F934DE.description: To analyze the dynamic relationships of people with land, environments, events, and ideas as they have affected the past, shape the present, and influence the future. (DR)

D201457189094D0AAF50904E3243EF85.description: Judge the influence and impact of worldview on the progress or decline of the societies studied.

C14B38FEFF9C4548A398E6866C848685.description: Explain how the worldview of Canadian First Nations, including the value placed on harmony and trust, led to the signing of Treaties.

A222FFE8385844478241CA4CE7E9FBE2.description: Analyse the influence of worldviews upon attitudes toward territorial expansion, colonization, or empire-building in the societies studied, and assess the impact of such activities on the indigenous cultures and peoples.

C90F1F6A073C4C28BA9FBA7BF471FD9E.description: Explain the influence of worldview on personal choices, decisions, and interactions (e.g., choice of friends, choice of fashion, the significance of education, participation or nonparticipation in events, choice of pastimes and recreational activities, approaches to nature and ecology, approaches to consumerism).

E86EB1841F9843F7B1081DEE16EAEDBB.description: Determine the influence of worldview on the choices, decisions, and interactions in a society.

9E9962A269C441B2AE5F78D52E1E4FA1.description: Investigate the worldview of the local community as represented through features including literature, the arts, cultural celebrations and traditions, education (including Elders’ teachings of indigenous peoples), sports and recreation, and architecture.

8CAD46151D6E4EFDA16C44EDB3C9336C.description: Examine the role of education in perpetuating the worldview of a society studied.

D6DA765CFC4740EBA70683459D4690E5.description: Analyze how works of art of a society studied reveal elements of that society’s worldview.

AEC2390A7A28452DB5241479C5D661B7.description: Identify the architectural features which communicate the worldview of a society studied.

F7A91434CE9949B7B4A4483D206825F4.description: Distinguish the worldviews represented in the literature of a society studied.

BEF400DC39174881BD7470D6BC25D504.description: Analyze the ways a worldview is expressed in the daily life of a society

A07BECE70DCB43BFB888410F89085717.description: Analyse the effects of ethnocentrism on indigenous peoples.

C7D33C17682A427CAC88A0287B1C3629.description: Investigate diverse historical views regarding the terms ‘primitive’ and ‘civilized’, and analyze the effect of the perceptions of the concepts on ethnocentrism in colonizers.

1C0F567A5C1440C5804720D5AE7B922E.description: Apply the definition of society to one of the civilizations studied, and detail ways in which the civilization meets the criteria to be considered a society (e.g., How can Mesopotamia be called a society according to the formulated definition? Would Aboriginal groupings of the plains and woodlands in North America meet the criteria?).

840A2E863EA94710A688AFEB3A27811B.description: Compare two different societies studied including the attributes of leaders, the roles of various individuals, cultural traditions and ceremonies, and means of sustenance.

9FC1B52EA1474069813AE1940127177A.description: Research a list of characteristics and attributes that formulate a definition of a society.

17B2CEA7A7324E88B6DC5799DC21ED69.description: Investigate the roles of individuals in the institutions of the local community, including the expectations attached to those roles (e.g., school: student, principal, teacher, caretaker, secretary; hospital: doctor, nurse, traditional healer, receptionist, paramedic, medical technician, patient).

853392C89BC34B5A992091EC3C824B29.description: Relate the functions and services of institutions in the community (e.g., schools, churches, local governments, parents, Elders, traditional knowledge keepers) to the needs of the people in that community.

88B2435994034D4D9E9DE93ADEFFD1E8.description: To examine the local, indigenous, and global interactions and interdependence of individuals, societies, cultures, and nations. (IN)
